text: English grammar lesson 6 topic verb
tenses our focus will be on the present
perfect and the present perfect
progressive in part 4 we'll practice
using time expressions and then we'll
finally turn our attention to
understanding and using the present
perfect progressive the two main kinds
of time expressions that we'll look at
our adverbs and prepositions let's look
at the most common ones first
the adverb ever is used in yes/no
questions to refer to the past in
general example have you ever ridden a
snowmobile meaning at any time in your
past
did you ride a snowmobile the adverb
never is used to express that an action
or event did not happen at any time in
the past example I've never visited
South America meaning I didn't visit
South America at any time in my past the
adverb already is used in questions or
statements to emphasize an unspecified
time before now first example has her
plane landed already meaning tell me yes
or no the time of landing isn't
important second example I've already
read that book meaning at some point in
the past I read it please note the
placement of already we can put it at
the end of a statement or just before
the past participle examples has her
plane landed already has her plane
already landed I've read that book
already I've already read that book
the adverb yet is used in negative
questions and statements to stress the
time before now it's the opposite of
already example why haven't you finished
yet
meaning why didn't you finish before now
example
Jennifer's latest video hasn't been
rated yet meaning no one rated it before
now the preposition for is used to state
a time period that began in the past and
continues to now so the focus is on
duration examples I've been married for
11 years we've been friends for a long
time the preposition since is used to
mark the start of a time period that
began in the past and continues to now
examples I've lived in New England since
2001 I haven't seen my brother since
last Christmas let's talk about sins as
a conjunction
since can also be used with a clause
that is a complete idea with a subject
and a verb here's an example I've known
her since we were little girls the
clause is we were little girls note that
in the clause we use the simple past
tense to mark the start of that time
period look at the difference between
since as a preposition and since as a
conjunction I've known her since we were
little girls I've known her since
childhood
the conjunction is followed by a clause
a complete idea with a subject and a
verb please don't confuse since and 4/4
is used to state periods of time
duration since is used to mark the
beginning of a time period a starting
point examples I've been married for 11
years I've been married since 1997 the
preposition in is used in the negative
to express how long an action hasn't
been done or how long an event hasn't
happened examples I haven't seen her in
years I haven't seen her
Agis I haven't seen her in a long time
in is most similar to four but we only
use in with the negative exercise one
choose the best word or phrase to
complete the statement number one choose
ever or already your clue is to ask
about general past experience the
question is have you ever been to the
beach on the East Coast to choose since
or in answer I've swum in the ocean many
times but I haven't been to the beach in
over two years number three
choose already or yet answer I visited
that Museum a few times already but I
wouldn't mind going again number four
choose already or yet answer there's one
section of that museum that I haven't
seen yet number five
choose since or four answer this is my
friend Cherie we've known each other
since grade school
number six choose in or for answer
sometimes it's hard to believe that
Sheree and I have been friends for more
than two decades to help you a bit more
and let me share some other time
expressions commonly used with the
present perfect
they are always often just still so far
for a while and at one time or another
let me give you examples
I've always wondered about that meaning
continually in the past and up to the
present time I've often thought about
you
meaning frequently in the past and up to
the present time I've just learned the
truth
this has emphasis on the recent past I
still haven't heard from him meaning yet
as in I haven't heard from him yet
that's the best work I've done so far
meaning up to now I've had this cold for
awhile
meaning for an unspecified or unknown
period of time usually not long another
way to say it is for some time I've seen
them together at one time or another
meaning on occasion from time to time
it's time now to talk about the present
perfect progressive some of you may know
it as the present perfect continuous let
me give you an example once upon a time
I was a traditional classroom teacher I
had a classroom desks chairs a
whiteboard but now I have a virtual
classroom and you're in it I've been
teaching online for just over a year why
did I say I have been teaching because I
want to emphasize the duration the
duration of about one year when you want
to emphasize the duration that began in
the past and continues to now we use the
present perfect progressive
this is an action that is not complete
yet let me explain again why we use the
present perfect progressive there are
two basic reasons not necessarily
separate but different reasons the first
to emphasize the duration of an action
that began in the past and continues to
now
the second reason is to express an
action that began in the past and is
still in progress it's unfinished not
complete let me give you two examples
I've been teaching English for more than
10 years I've been researching software
that could help me make better videos in
both examples we have an action that
began in the past and continues to the
present both actions are incomplete but
in the first we have that added emphasis
on duration I'm telling you how long
it's been in the second we're simply
saying that this action is not yet
finished note both the present perfect
and the present perfect progressive can
emphasize the duration of a time period
that began in the past and continues to
now but if the verb expresses no action
just a state or condition then the
progressive is not used
here are two examples I've known my
neighbors all my life I've been a fan of
sting since the 1980s both the verb know
and B Express a state it's very unusual
to use them in a progressive tense
forming the present perfect progressive
is not difficult you need to helping
verbs have been or has been followed by
the present participle a verb in the ing
let's give you some practice doing this
exercise to complete each statement with
the present perfect progressive number
one read the statement to yourself first
over the past few days my husband has
been watching a series of documentaries
on physics he finds it interesting to
learn about the structure of atoms to
answer my son has been asking for a
wagon for Christmas ever since he saw
one in a book he got from the library
three answer my brother and I have been
trying to learn more information about
our relatives from past generations he
really got me interested by starting a
family tree online about a year ago
